article_text:
Coverage on this live blog has ended, please click here for the latest developments

Ukrainian forces kept hold of the capital city of Kyiv Saturday as a senior U.S. Defense official said there were signs the invading Russian forces were frustrated by fiercer-than-expected resistance.

Here's what to know now:

In a major shift, Germany announced it would join the list of countries sending military assistance to Ukraine — and said it was considering a "targeted" approach to disconnecting Russia from the SWIFT banking system.

The U.S. continues to see indications of viable Ukrainian resistance, a senior U.S. Defense Department official said Saturday. Moscow was particularly stymied by the fight Ukrainians have put up in the north around Kyiv and Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, the official said.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has refused to leave the capital. Instead he has been posting videos from the streets, urging his people to join him in defiance.

Follow our in-depth coverage of the Russia-Ukraine crisis here.

Air raid sirens were heard in the city of Lviv in western Ukraine.

As the Russian invasion into Ukraine continues, air raid sirens were sounded across the city of Lviv in western Ukraine. Air raid sirens were sounded in Kyiv on Thursday and shortly after that, Russian missiles began taking over the skies above Ukraine.

Now, with air raid sirens being sounded in Lviv, the possibility arises that Russia is not finished in Ukraine. More aerial attacks could also be inbound. The information was shared on Twitter by news organisation BNO News. Lviv is a city which is around 70 km away from the Polish-Ukrainian border.

WATCH: Air raid sirens wail across Lviv in western Ukraine pic.twitter.com/Qu18aRqyGh — BNO News (@BNONews) February 25, 2022

On Thursday, news agency AFP stated that Russian forces took over Hostomel (Gostomel) airfield, a cargo airport near Kyiv, which is also known as Antonov airport.

Also Read: Ukraine's tragedy turns into spectator sport as thousands watch 'Russia special invasion'

However, Ukraine's armed forces are claiming that the raid by Russia on Antonov International Airport in Hostomel had failed. Officials said that the airport was under the control of the Ukrainian army.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, on Thursday, called on citizens who are willing to defend the country from Russian forces to come forward. He said that Kyiv will issue weapons to everyone who wants them.

The Ukrainian army provided 10,000 assault rifles to locals to defend the country, Kyiv media reported on Friday.

Also Read: Actor Sean Penn in Ukraine to continue filming documentary on Russian invasion

photo from the open sources

An alarm siren sounded this morning, February 26, at about 6:10 p.m. It was caused by the emergence of a plane flying in the direction of Belarus. This was announced during a briefing by the head of the Lviv Regional State Administration Maksym Kozytskyi.

«This morning in Lviv, a siren sounded because of the intersection of the Lviv region’s airspace. It was entered by a plane flying in the direction of Belarus,» Maksym Kozytskyi said.

Also this morning, a Ukrainian fighter jet conducted an emergency landing in Zolochiv, Lviv region. The pilot is alive.

It will be recalled that checkpoints are being set up in Lviv and suburbs – at the entrance and exit of the city. Currently, the situation in the Lviv region is under control. The checkpoints will check the people who will enter the city. They are set up together with the police and territorial defense to maintain security in Lviv. Read more here.

Olha Shveda, translated by Vitalii Holich

Lviv Now is an English-language website for Lviv, Ukraine’s «tech-friendly cultural hub.» It is produced by Tvoe Misto («Your City») media-hub, which also hosts regular problem-solving public forums to benefit the city and its people.

Lviv’s mayor is telling the city’s residents to take shelter as air raid sirens ring out in the city.

The city, in western Ukraine, has so far been mostly sheltered from the fighting. A large number of Western diplomats, including Israel’s, moved to Lviv from Kyiv ahead of the Russian invasion.

The reason for the air raid sirens is not immediately clear, but Sky News reports that missiles struck an airport in Rivne, between Kyiv and Lviv.

In Kyiv, Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky said the government had information that “subversive groups” were encroaching on the city, and US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said it “could well be under siege” in what US officials believe is a brazen attempt by Russian President Vladimir Putin to dismantle the government and replace it with his own regime.

US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin told lawmakers on a phone call that Russian mechanized forces that entered from Belarus were about 20 miles from Kyiv, according to a person familiar with the call.

Air raid sirens could be heard sounding on the streets of Lviv early on Friday morning.

In a statement posted of Facebook at 06:09 (local time; 04:09 GMT), Lviv mayor Andriy Sadovyi said "Lviv, you need to go to the shelter. A siren has just sounded, which means an air alarm."

This post was followed up with another at 07:30 local time (05:30 GMT) with Sadovyi telling residents it was safe to leave shelter.

Russia launched its invasion across Ukraine inthe early hours of Thursday, in a move strongly condemned by world leaders,including the EU and the US.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said 137 civilians and military personnel were killed in the country on the first day of Russia's offensive.
